prompt.p: A 20-year-old man presents complaining of polydipsia, polyuria, weakness and fatigue. His test results are:
2 hour value in oral glucose tolerance test 6.0 mmol/L(normal range <7.8 mmol/L)
Serum adjusted calcium 2.4 mmol/L (normal range 2.1–2.6 mmol/L)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone syndrome (SIADH)

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Diabetes insipidus) is Correct. The glucose tolerance test is normal (<7.8 mmol/L is normal, >11.1 mmol/L is diabetes mellitus). Serum calcium is normal; however, creatinine, urea, sodium and potassium are high with a high plasma osmolality. The opposite occurs in SIADH. Urine osmolality postdesmopressin increases (800 mmol/kg) in cranial DI but remains low (300 mmol/kg) in nephrogenic DI.
Option B (Diabetes mellitus) is Incorrect. The glucose in this patient is normal and not hyperglycaemic as expected in diabetes mellitus.
Option C (Hyperparathyroidism) is Incorrect. The adjusted calcium level is in the normal range.
Option D (Hyperthryroidism) is Incorrect. The features present do not suggest this diagnosis.
Option E (SIADH) is Incorrect. Investigation would show a low creatinine, urea, sodium, potassium and plasma osmolality.
